Though the parking at the foot of Tamarack Ave. is now a pay lot, we always manage to find street parking. The beach is well maintained, has a popular surf break, has good surf fishing and seems there's always someone in the water. A walled, winding promenade runs just above sand level from Tamarack to Pine Ave.; no dogs allowed on the promenade or the beach. Also, no beach fires, no alcohol on the beach. Stairs connect the promenade to the above sidewalk on Carlsbad Blvd. (dogs allowed on sidewalk) at several intervals along the way. Bathrooms are located at Tamarack and Pine Ave ends where you'll also find outside cold showers to wash sand from your whatever. The beachside sidewalk along Carlsbad Blvd. is very popular for dog walkers, runners, strollers, etc. In summer, it's common for RV's to park along the road to enjoy the view and use the grassy area next to the sidewalk. North of the Pine Ave terminus, there's a large grassy area, and beyond that are restaurants and some touristy stuff. You'll also find permanent beach volleyball nets in the sand north of the Pine Ave. end. A great place to enjoy the beach environment, take a walk.

Carlsbad State Beach is an overlooked gem in Northern San Diego County. The beach is inviting, the swimming is good, and there's surfing too! This beach is just south of the State Campground and it has multiple personalities. The section of the beach that is south of the jetty is often crowded with families and groups enjoying their day at the beach. The are just north of the jetty is wide and sandy, but it's often the site of large beach volleyball tournaments. Further north, the section by the campground is quieter and more secluded. This is our favorite part of Carlsbad State Beach, between the bluffs and the waves, away from the crowds and the noise and the traffic on 101. Ahh, nothing like a relaxing day at the beach! P.S. Parking at the north end is very limited, but you can always find a spot on the east side of PCH; go up Avenida Encinas one short block, and turn left onto Ponto Drive.

Camping on the coast - beautiful beach

One of the few campgrounds right on the coast but what makes this one special is the beach down below. There is pretty small day use parking lot (free) on the north and then Ponto beach state park to the south, so mainly the people on the beach are from the campground or the hotel across the street.

The campground is in good shape. Has 222 sites (there are some sites that have full hookup). Has restrooms, water spickets every few lots, a small store (in case you forgot anything), shaved ice and most of the sites are fairly large in size. You book them 6 months out, but book early (basically right when your 6 month window opens) as they are reserved quickly. We saw a few people when we were there that were squatting at the check-in waiting for cancellations.

The campground is on a bluff with stairways down to the beach (with a ramp on the south side). This was our last chance to get away with the grandkids before back to school (remember how that felt?). We were lucky enough to get our favorite site (#206) once again. This site has stairs down to the beach right next to it and super convenient to take breaks for lunch, dinner etc.

Two nice walkways and a great beach

I have walked the beach hundreds of times over the past 55 years. The developed beach used to end at the breakwater. Then after some severe erosion, the next half mile of beach was developed. Finally the land which was off-limits owned by the power company was added.

After severe erosion caused by the expansion of the Oceanside harbor, the seawall and its walkway was built and at the same time the roadside walkway was constructed. This makes for nice walking and plenty of people do so.

The slope has been planted with new drought resistant plants and the non-native plants eliminated. Wood fires are no longer allowed on the beach and the previous fire circles have been removed. Propane fires are o.k.

There are lifeguard towers, not all manned on this Wednesday. Only three people were in the water. Today was the smallest, actually non-existant surf I have ever seen here.

Normally there is good surfing just north of the breakwater, at the surfing spot known as 'Tamarack', named for the street which is perpendicular to the spot.

Restrooms are clean and well-kept, and there is a walking path between the street level and the beach that makes for a wonderful saunter without sand. Something for everyone.

It's about 4 miles to the Oceanside pier so you can get almost 8 miles round trip in if you're up for a long run or stroll. You can also stroll to Carlsbad Village - shop & eat and stroll back. Or you can go South, but you'll need to walk or swim around the jetty. It's less populated heading in this direction and there are some scenic bluffs around the corner.It is expensive paid parking in the lot a Tamarack so find a free parking spot along the coast or up a block. You can walk on the sidewalk above for a nice view or on the beach and short beach walk area. There's a group that meets at 6PM on weekdays for mile+ ocean swims and they welcome guests. This is also where the Carlsbad Triathlon takes place. Lots of locals surf here as does the high school surf team. You can also rent boogie boards and surfboards about a mile North behind the Fish House. (Incidently, a great spot for fish & chips & happy hour.)
The only negative is that the bathrooms are frequently FILTHY. Don't understand how people can be such slobs and why the State doesn't clean it up more than they do since they are getting plenty of $$ for parking. Sigh.
